(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1924, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

MISCELLANEOUS VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth?

How many of these were bachelor's homes? None

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors?

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Sometimes on a Sunday but often each day or night.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Most visiting done without an invitation.

What time of the day did you go in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Usually in the afternoon or after supper.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Yes.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly (that is, was the term "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) Everyone was always welcome.

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in?

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? The whole family went.

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Yes we had a bee for a splitting barn yard.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, dances, drives or dances in homes? Describe. In the earliest years there were not many parties. There were a few dances in homes.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates. Yes as our young folks grew up we often had dances in our homes.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? Sometimes one farmer and his family came along with his team and sleigh and picked up one or two families and went to a third home to play cards. This turned out rather oddly one
afternoon, the one neighbor said we invited to the last house for a turkey supper. The rest of us had a little supper but this neighbor could not arrive at our destination there was no sign of supper but little falls out on cards and a dish of apples on top. On the way this neighbor was traveled considerably and where sandwiches were passed around he was urged to eat hearty we knew he was hungry years after we told our friends about it and they had a hearty laugh over it.
afternoon, the one neighbor said we were invited to the last house for a turkey supper. The rest of us had a little supper but this neighbor would not. When we arrived at our destination there was no sign of supper but little tables set out for cards and a dish of apples on each. On the sly this neighbor was teased considerably and when sandwiches were passed around he was urged to eat hearty we knew he was hungry. Years after we told our guests about it and they had a hearty laugh over it.
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, proms, etc., if you have not described them elsewhere.) Describe how your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district.

9. When was your first community hall built? What material was it made of? Who built it? - the community through grass-roots funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? How did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district meetings, and make use of the hall for all gatherings?) We used the hall monthly as we nearly all had corn snow.

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in questions 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for at these parties?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

11. What card games were popular in the early days? - Bridge, Whist, Euchre

Was there card playing for a prize?

What dances were popular?

Was there ever any disarrangement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it; either as an entertainment in the larger or for community gatherings? Explain. Every man accepted it.
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community meetings, box socials, and other activities. (Christian also the school, Christmas trees, picnics, etc.)

9. When was your first community hall built? What material was used? Who built it? - In four.

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in houses, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 6, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

11. What card games were popular? Square dances and waltzes and schottisches.

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the school district, or for community gatherings? Explain. Every one accepted it.
12. That attempt at formality, or "snobbery," do you remember in small towns, such as those in which calling, calling cards, visits were treated ceremonially.

13. Was the children's known in your community? Yes

Describe what you remember about children, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them.

Usually the couple had lunch ready and invited the bunch in for lunch and for games.

14. Describe any other details of meetings, parties, etc., that you can remember, telling of any plans or arrangements not already mentioned that were made in visiting or social life between neighbors.

After the telephone came we never went visiting without first calling our friends up.

GENERAL

Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainments, sports, reading, music or pioneer days, not already mentioned.

For a number of years our school was used by the Community for Whist drives and dances. After the piano was purchased and donated, all considered putting the piano in the school. The pupils think it will be used again. The pupils and teachers are purchasing a radio as well.
